medical_history.chief_complaint: Sudden-onset angina secondary to a 90% obstructive lesion along the proximal left anterior descending coronary artery.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Symptoms began suddenly due to a 90% obstructive lesion. The patient developed in-stent restenosis after percutaneous transluminal angioplasty and required repeated interventions, including cutting balloon angioplasty and brachytherapy, and eventually single-vessel bypass surgery after a high-grade occlusion reoccurred with a recurrence of angina.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and in-stent restenosis. Previous interventions include percutaneous transluminal angioplasty with stenting and single-vessel bypass surgery. The patient improved their lipid profile with medications including simvastatin and niacin.
medical_history.family_history: Significant for the patient's father, who died of a myocardial infarction at age 44 years.
medical_history.social_history: The patient does not smoke and is not hypertensive. There is no mention of alcohol consumption or other lifestyle factors.
